title: Dave McCleave
text:
David Edward McCleave (24 December 1911 – 19 May 1988) was an <a href="England">English</a> <a href="Boxing">boxer</a> who competed for <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> in the <a href="1932%20Summer%20Olympics">1932 Summer Olympics</a>. He was born in <a href="Battersea">Battersea</a>. He fought as Dave McCleave.
Boxing career.
In 1932 he finished fourth in the <a href="Boxing%20at%20the%201932%20Summer%20Olympics%20-%20Men%27s%20welterweight">welterweight class</a>. He was not able to compete in the bronze medal bout against <a href="Bruno%20Ahlberg">Bruno Ahlberg</a>. At the 1934 Empire Games he won the <a href="gold%20medal">gold medal</a> in the <a href="welterweight">welterweight</a> class after winning the final against <a href="Dick%20Barton%20%28boxer%29">Dick Barton</a>.
He won the 1932 and 1934 <a href="England%20Boxing">Amateur Boxing Association</a> British <a href="England%20Boxing%20National%20Amateur%20Championships%20Welterweight%20Champions">welterweight titles</a> and the 1931 <a href="England%20Boxing%20National%20Amateur%20Championships%20Lightweight%20Champions">lightweight title</a>, when boxing out of the Lynn ABC.
Personal life.
In the 1950s he was the <a href="Pub%20landlord">landlord</a> of the Union Tavern Pub <a href="Camberwell%20New%20Road">Camberwell New Road</a>. It was a boxing pub where David Benjamin Gray was compere and manager with his wife Irene Alice Gray.
